content: Hi @WG-traits almost meeting time :)

Link to agenda hackmd: https://hackmd.io/nrhN5A8sR2eY9UdfJTKcJg
Link to sprint goals: https://hackmd.io/D_wskAmRT52zL9xmhmg0Kg
agenda hackmd is a bit out of date :/
I've been pretty bad at keeping it updated recently
Yeah, I keep meaning to spend some time updating docs but haven't gotten to it
Last week for the sprint
That said, I'm not sure what we want to talk about
last week, we did some much needed triage
Maybe we can start with annoucements
It was a fairly active week
8 merged PRs
One thing I wanted to talk about was our post-sprint plans
I think we talked about trying to take a bit of a "summer break"
though a few of those were last Tuesday
Sorry @detrumi I didn't get around to giving you feedback btw, have that on my list
but we did merge the .chalk file writer PR :)
woot!
I actually would like to go through a couple of the issues that have a code example and see if I can get a reproducing program out of them
(I'm not even sure if they are still issues)
might be useful to check on the sprint goal status
in terms of this meeting

nikomatsakis said:

I think we talked about trying to take a bit of a "summer break"

I think that's a good idea
so one thing is that I don't know my july/august plans but I'm definitely taking at least a 2 week vacation in there
Should we try to plan to start a new sprint in Sept
we could say that we will suspend meetings until september
and try to continue pushing in a less structured fashion
that's also not a bad idea
That'd give us a chance to finish the current goals also
right, basically keep on developing plans towards current goals
considering the past few meetings have been somewhat adhoc
looking over the sprint goals...
we've only "finished" about half of them
We might've been overly ambitious on some of them
Eh
Yeah, so, we may have been a bit ambitious, but I think also it's a sign we may need a bit of a break to refocus :)
I think some are just pretty broad
But also there's a few that have in-progress PRs
yeah, I'm getting the sense from the lack of completion on the sprint goals and lack of meeting topics that people are getting drained :)

I would really like to see us reformulating the skill-tree and laying out more concrete steps. I feel particularly that I'd like to see work towards the shared rustc type library but I admit I've been a bit hesitant to set people off doing big renamings and refactorings for some reason ;)
I guess I tink a vacation is a good idea but I would like to also use the time to do a bit of "recharging and prep", of course maybe's..you know..not a vacation :)
I know the feeling, I'm planning to use part of my vacation to work on some chalk things :slight_smile:
by vacation, you mean spending days working on chalk?
oof, beat me
well, yeah kind of :)
though when I said 2/3 weeks vacation I didn't mean that ;)
though it's definitely true sitting down to code for a few hours feels like a vacation to me :)
Indeed :)
So, we could go over the sprint goals
But I feel like we've all seen them at this point
yeah
So, maybe we should just pick a couple that are somewhat up in the air
I mostly want to know if the notes are up to date
I think so
the crate/structure one is a bit out of date
you have a tentative PR
let's just go but try not to get bogged down
and take some notes on current status
and @lcnr's forall PR
chalk crate structure and publishing
I think that the status here is that we are thinking of an "inverted" setup
and we have a preliminary prototype
I have to admit that while I think I favor this direction, it makes me a bit "sad"
in that the generic types don't show the things that are "opaque"
But I still think it's right :)
You mean like Forest?
and such
Note that this does also give us a clearer path forward for things like salsa wrapping for the recursive solver
Does it?
In the end I just think the generics was kind of too messy
beautiful in theory, annoying in practice
anyway, I was writing some notes in the hackmd
At least in my mind
it may, I'm not sure
we did not yet do bors
I forgot what the status of that was
@Pietro Albini said we could use regular bors
I can't remember if @Pietro Albini was working on that, or if there was something we needed to do
but I forgot to follow up with them
Goal: improve caching strategy for recursive solver
So, I think the status here is that we laid out a plan to handle co-induction
and I sketched out how salsa should work
but we got stuck in the question of negative cycles
I suspect we want to just rule them out
I think that's fine
but I still have to persuade myself by elaborating a bit more how specialization should work
but I realize that this realy shouldn't stop us from moving forward
since it doesn't change all that much about how things work really, I don't think
Plus, it doesn't make a ton of sense to handle negative cycles in the recursive solver, since SLG doesn't handle them
well both or neither
hmm
GAT support in rustc
seems like lots of work here by @lcnr :)
so, lcnr did a PR, we've been talking about how to make it more beautiful
I :hearts: beautiful code
Goal: Extracting a shared library representing types
No progress?
basically no
Looking at the tracking issue, chalk is almost done but rustc work stalled?
yeah, but really there's more work on chalk side too
/me feels guilty :)

Jack Huey said:

seems like lots of work here by lcnr :)

In relation to GAT? I can't quite follow you here
Yeah, I think we just need someone to pick up the rustc side too
the forall-work is kind of part of GAT
actually @Matthew Jasper has landed a number of great PRs there too that we can retcon as part of the effort ;)
I'm working on another now...
probalby he and I should touch base a bit, as I'm sure there's progress to be made and i'm not sure what exactly is on the short path
even better
That's exciting
... and am very sad that we don't have lazy norm because getting the normalize calls correct has been such a pain.
So...I've been thinking about the next thing to do in rustc...and it feels like it may be worth exploring lazy norm there again :)
I really just want to get chalk to work in rustc at like 90% working
@Matthew Jasper do you want to throw some links to PRs in the sprint hackmd ?
well, 100% is the goal. But I feel like not until we hit like 90-95% working will we really get a sense of where things might be something that needs to be really thought about/decided
also maybe we should just rewrite that to "matthew jasper" as the "Who"
@Matthew Jasper welcome to WG-traits :)
you have been drafted
I would say that the predicate/for-all stuff also fits on the "extract shared library" gal
oh, for sure
and maybe even fits there better, now that we are working on the refactoring of how we handle associated type bounds
so it's not really zero progress :)
/me moves them
anyway, next goal?
were those ty.kindrefactors the part you were reluctant to start on?
yes, but I really shouldn't be
those steps are actually ones I think we should just do
they seem pretty straightforward
again, I think it's mostly just about someone picking them up
I can write-up an MCP today perhaps
and we can advertise it out
That works
the late-bound lifetimes and binder stuff is deeper and harder but
we don't have to start there :)
so, if there is an MCP, is it also worth maybe an issue filed?
(on rust-lang/rust)
I don't know that we did much here, though I see "tracing support" is listed under it
Goal: increase Chalk performance (very open-ended)

Jack Huey said:

so, if there is an MCP, is it also worth maybe an issue filed?

yeah, I'll do that too
yeah, besides tracing, nothing
But tracing is great
This seems like an interesting project that someone can pick up, now t hat tracing is in
I'm interested in working on moving lifetimes to be closer to Chalk's (notable, having fewer variants)
Goal: Experiments
I think this is just equivalence edges -- no progress there I think?
So, I did actually look at this a bit
I couldn't actually find any literature on equivalence edges
2) The sort of direction I wanted to take I think is blocked on sem-syn equality
ah yeah
So I then started looking at that and got blocked and ran out of time there
Goal: Writing a .chalk file (draft PR)
landed initial prototype
Yes
I think this is pretty functional
There are some followup items
is it 'integrated' into rust-analyzer?
But it looks pretty usable
Nope
I mean
that seems like a good next step, and/or writing up how to use it in that context
Once rust-analyzer updates, there's a few `_name functions to implement
And they'll have to use the LoggingRustIrDatabase somewhere
ok.
I can talk with @Florian Diebold sometime
I'm excited about this :)
yeah, sounds really useful for tracking bugs and performance issues
Goal: improve opaque types support
No movement on PRs :)
I've gotten mostly stuck on that
Sounds like just waiting on @nikomatsakis's comments :)
Goal: extend chalk to support Rust semantics
@Aaron Hill is working on generators, I think
seems like we made quite good progrss here
overall
Adt PR, I didn't merge, since I guess it needs tests for auto semantics
I'm almost ready to open up my generator pr
sorry that it's taken so long
but yeah, overall great progress

Aaron Hill said:

sorry that it's taken so long

no worries :hearts:
Cool, people on the rust-analyzer side were asking for that, to support async blocks I think
Sorry - I was planning to finish up this week but covid has really been a nightmare the last couple of weeks
And I've been working on the subtype PR
If someone could help me out by writing down a definitive list of tests or something it would be massively appreciated
I should have that done by the end of the week, assuming I don't run into anything unexpected
@Nathan Corbyn sure, I'll comment on the PR
Thank you so much
Thank you!
I've been doing some work on TypeOutlives also, I should be able to open a PR once I get chalk#543 done and merged
the rustc types are now connected to buildin types, right @Jack Huey ?
On the rustc integration side, I think all the types that we have are conected
yes
So yeah, excellent progress
Goal: Handle region constraints in rustc integration
I'm going to be honest, I have no clue what this was supposed to be
LifetimeOutlives and TypeOutlives?
(having some hackmd connectivity issues here)
I believe this was supposed to be :
• translating lifetime-outlives, type-outlives goals
• and extending chalk to report those constraints back to rustc and then having rustc translate them to actual region constraints
okay, lifetime outlives is translating
ohh
yeah, basically anything to do with translating things back, unless it's ints or floats doesn't work
but lifetimes and params will be exceptionally hard since they're handling specially
Goal: const generics and chalk
nothing new here I don't think
We don't have an issue filed for these...
I'm gonna do that
But I don't think it's blocking anything either
in the short term
nope
Goal: semantic vs syntactic equality
No progress
I haven't heard much from @Areredify, presumably they got busy
Probably
(sorry, got called afk for a bit)
I might just take a look at the sem-syn PR again after subtyping is finished
I might reach out privately, this might be a good project to try and recruit for others if they're busy
that works too
Goal: Document solver details in the Chalk book
I don't think the open points are really relevant any more?
mmm, I still think so
I think btw re: region/lifetime solving we can integrate that work into "extend chalk to support rust semantics" goal
(I'm sort of editing the doc to get it in shape to serve as our "sprint summary")
I feel like just adding a section into the glossary like "common syntax"
(well, i'll just add a few things)
I have a question:
* [ ] Auto trait handling for builtin chalk types
this is an open bullet from earlier, what's the status here? is there a chalk issue?
No chalk issue :/
We should open one
would that be a table-style tracking issue?

• Goal: Handle region constraints in rustc integration
    * Who? Jack
    * We integrated lifetime-outlives goals into chalk and are working on making the mechanism more elegant in #538.
    * We need to extend rustc to translate the chalk region constraints back into rustc region constraints.
Honestly, I don't see any reason they all can't be done in one PR
Oh wait, we have this: https://rust-lang.github.io/chalk/book/clauses/well_known_traits.html#current-state
(right?)
@nikomatsakis looks good :)
whoops, I apparently did not update that table in the closure PR
:face_palm:‍♀️
well, at least you got reminded now
regarding const generics --
is that integrated with rustc at all?
yes
Tests for it are lacking I think
but like arrays do lower the const len
for sem-syn equality, the next step I think @Areredify and I had in mind was https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/issues/512
which is kind of a cleanup/refactoring
OK, well, this was helpful
we actually did a heck of a lot this sprint it seems ;)
though I'm kind of forgetting what happened during each sprint
Oh, for sure we got a lot accomplished
not sure what to do about next week
But indeed, I think we were a bit too ambitious with some goals
So, next week
I think can just be another sprint recap
But
I don't think we need a full meeting
But I'll be around
And write up a blog post
so I'll sort of go through things here
ah right, yeah that's a good idea
That is, unless anybody wants to have a meeting for something
I think taht all sounds good
this was helpful for highlighting a few areas that are stuck
Let's plan to pick back up on regularly meetings Sept. 1st
I feel like these kind of survey meetings are really useful to me, I wonder if there are ways to make them more efficient
(or around there)
or if they're just fine as they are :)
I think they're really helpful, yeah
seems fine, it's not like we overshot the timebox
I also find them inspirational
without pre-planning, I don't know if there's more to do
so they're useful in two ways :)
btw, amybe a silly idea but...
I wonder if it'd be useful to make labels for our sprint goals
and then tag PRs and issues with those labels?
Plus, we always seem to find things where we haven't filed issues or things like that
i.e., so that we could like review "what is the set of PRs that landed related to X"
So, I've thought about that
We'd have to tone down the number of goals a bit, I think
well, less about post-review
that...might be a good idea regardless
although labels are cheap :)
anyway leave it aside for now
It's not a terrible idea :)
heh, that just makes it sound like a bad idea
has anyone looked at https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/graphs/code-frequency
it's super interesting to look at the uptick in activity since we started the sprints
I wish you could zoom in
It's even more clear in https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/graphs/commit-activity
Nice to see the sustained progress lately
Just wanted to thank all of @WG-traits again for all of your hard work the past few months :)
(Rather than labels, another option would be to use GH Projects or to use Milestones)
